text: Adoration to the Highest Self! Hari h , Om!

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1. Suke s as 1 Bhâradvâ g a 2 , and S aivya Satyakâma, and Sauryâya n in 3 Gârgya, and Kausalya 4 Â s valâyana, and Bhârgava Vaidarbhi 5 , and Kabandhin Kâtyâyana, these were devoted to Brahman, firm in Brahman, seeking for the Highest Brahman. They thought that the venerable Pippalâda could tell them all that, and they therefore took fuel in their hands (like pupils), and approached him.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. That Ri shi said to them: 'Stay here a year longer, with penance, abstinence, and faith; then you may ask questions according to your pleasure, and if we know them, we shall tell you all.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. Then 6 Kabandhin Kâtyâyana approached him and asked: 'Sir, from whence may these creatures be born?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. He replied: 'Pra g âpati (the lord of creatures) was desirous of creatures (pra g â h ). He performed penance' 1 , and having performed penance, he produces a pair, matter (rayi) and spirit (prâ n a), thinking that they together should produce creatures for him in many ways.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5 2 . The sun is spirit, matter is the moon. All this, what has body and what has no body, is matter, and therefore body indeed is matter.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. Now Âditya, the sun, when he rises, goes toward the East, and thus receives the Eastern spirits into his rays. And when he illuminates the South, the West, the North, the Zenith, the Nadir, the intermediate quarters, and everything, he thus receives all spirits into his rays.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. Thus he rises, as Vai s vânara, (belonging to all men,) assuming all forms, as spirit, as fire. This has been said in the following verse:

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8 3 . (They knew) him who assumes all forms, the golden 4 , who knows all things, who ascends highest, alone in his splendour, and warms us; the thousand-rayed, who abides in a hundred places, the spirit of all creatures, the Sun, rises.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. The year indeed is Pra g âpati, and there are two paths thereof, the Southern and the Northern. Now those who here believe in sacrifices and pious gifts as work done, gain the moon only as their

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: [paragraph continues] (future) world, and return again. Therefore the Ri shis who desire offspring, go to the South, and that path of the Fathers is matter (rayi).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. But those who have sought the Self by penance, abstinence, faith, and knowledge, gain by the Northern path Âditya, the sun. This is the home of the spirits, the immortal, free from danger, the highest. From thence they do not return, for it is the end. Thus says the S loka 1 :

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. Some call him the father with five feet (the five seasons), and with twelve shapes (the twelve months), the giver of rain in the highest half of heaven; others again say that the sage is placed in the lower half, in the chariot 2 with seven wheels and six spokes.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 12. The month is Pra g âpati; its dark half is matter, its bright half spirit. Therefore some Ri shis perform sacrifice in the bright half, others in the other half.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 13. Day and Night 3 are Pra g âpati; its day is spirit, its night matter. Those who unite in love by day waste their spirit, but to unite in love by night is right.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 14. Food is Pra g âpati. Hence proceeds seed, and from it these creatures are born.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 15. Those therefore who observe this rule of Pra g âpati (as laid down in § 13), produce a pair, and to them belongs this Brahma-world here 4 . But

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: those in whom dwell penance, abstinence, and truth,

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 16. To them belongs that pure Brahma-world, to them, namely, in whom there is nothing crooked, nothing false, and no guile.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 271:1 Suke s as seems better than Suke s an, and he is so called in the sixth Pra s ñ a, in MS. Mill 74.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 271:2 Bhâradvâ g a, S aivya, Gârgya, Âsvalâyana, Bhârgava, and Kâtyâyana are, according to S aṅkara, names of gotras or families.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 271:3 Sûryasyâpatya m Saurya h , tadapatya m S auryâya n i h . Dîrgha h sulopa s k a kh ândasa iti sa eva Sauryâya n î.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 271:4 Kausalyo nâmata h , kosalâyâm bhavo vâ.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 271:5 Vaidarbhi is explained as vidarbhe h prabhava h , or Vidarbheshu prabhava h . Vidarbha, a country, south of the Vindhya mountains, with Ku n d ina as its capital. Vaidarbha, a king of the Vidarbhas, is mentioned in the Ait. Brâhm. VII, 34. Vaidarbhi is a patronymic of Vidarbha. See B. R. s. v.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 271:6 After the year was over.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 272:1 Or he meditated; see Upanishads, vol. i, p. 238, n. 3.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 272:2 S aṅkara explains, or rather obscures, this by saying that the sun is breath, or the eater, or Agni, while matter is the food, namely, Soma.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 272:3 Cf. Maitr. Up. VI, 8.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 272:4 Hari n am is explained as ra s mimantam, or as harati sarveshâm prâ n inâm âyû m shi bhaumân vâ rasân iti hari n a h . I prefer to take it in the sense of yellow, or golden.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 273:1 Ri g-veda I, 164, 12. We ought to read upare vi k aksha n am.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 273:2 Sapta k akre, i.e. rathe. The seven wheels are explained as the rays or horses of the sun; or as half-years, seasons, months, half-months, days, nights, and muhûrtas.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 273:3 Taken as one, as a Nychthemeron.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 273:4 In the moon, reached by the path of the Fathers.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
